title: 112_hr6561
content:
The "Teachers and First Responders Back to Work Act of 2012" authorizes grants to States for teacher stabilization to prevent layoffs and create jobs in public education for the 2012-2014 school years. The Secretary reserves funds for assistance to outlying areas, the Secretary of the Interior, and administration and oversight of the program. The Secretary allocates funds to each State based on population ratios for individuals aged 5 through 17 and total population. Reallocation occurs if a State does not receive a grant. The Secretary reallocates funds to States based on population ratios for individuals aged 5 through 17 and total population. If a State does not receive a grant, the Secretary will reallocate that State's grant to other States receiving grants. SEC. 103. STATE APPLICATION. State seeking a grant under this title must submit an application to the Secretary within 30 days of enactment, ensuring maintenance of support for early childhood, elementary, and secondary education at or above fiscal year 2011 levels. The State must maintain education support at or above 2011 levels to be eligible for a grant. A chief executive can opt out of receiving funds by submitting a letter with an explanation. The Secretary can waive requirements for a State facing exceptional circumstances or financial decline. SEC. 104. STATE GRANTS. State grants under this title require each State to reserve a portion of the funds for State-funded early learning programs and administrative costs. The remaining grant funds are to be used for awards to local educational agencies to support early childhood, elementary, and secondary public education. The State shall distribute the remaining grant funds through subgrants to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios and funds received under part A of title I of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. The State must distribute grant funds to local educational agencies based on enrollment ratios and funds received under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965. A State receiving a grant under this title must make subgrants available to local educational agencies within 100 days. The State is prohibited from using grant funds to establish or supplement a rainy-day fund, supplant State funds, or reduce debt obligations. The State is prohibited from using grant funds to establish, restore, or supplement a rainy-day fund, reduce or retire debt obligations, or supplant State funds to reduce debt. Local educational agencies receiving subgrants must use funds for employee-related expenses to provide educational services. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 106 of the document outlines that State-funded early learning programs must use funds for educator compensation and hiring. Funds must be obligated by September 30, 2014. SEC. 107 requires states to report on fund usage and job support. SEC. 108 provides definitions. SEC. 108 defines key terms such as "local educational agency" and "State-funded early learning program". SEC. 109 authorizes $30 billion for the grant program in fiscal years 2012 and 2013. TITLE II--FIRST RESPONDER STABILIZATION

Purpose: Provide funds to States and localities to prevent layoffs and support job creation for law enforcement officers and firefighters.

Firefighter Grant Program: SEC. 202. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to make competitive grants to hire, rehire, and retain firefighters and maintain resources for fire departments. An additional $1 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 for this purpose. The Secretary of Homeland Security is authorized to reserve up to $2,000,000 for administrative costs for fiscal years 2012 and 2013. SEC. 203. LAW ENFORCEMENT OFFICER GRANT PROGRAM. The Attorney General will provide grants to hire, rehire, and retain law enforcement officers under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. An additional $4 billion is authorized for fiscal years 2012 and 2013, with a portion reserved for administrative costs.
